channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Putin Acknowledges Mistakes in Carrying Out His Draft
item.description: The Russian president’s remarks, which were shown on state television, came after anger with the draft spilled over into street protests across Russia.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents crossing a destroyed bridge amid the sounds of shelling in Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Despite Iran’s Efforts to Block Internet, Technology Has Helped Fuel Outrage
item.description: Online, Iranians engage in a world their leaders don’t want them to see.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Iranian demonstrators taking to the streets of the capital, Tehran, during a protest days after a young woman, Mahsa Amini, died in police custody after she was accused of violating the country’s headscarf law.

item.title: On Eve of Election, Bolsonaro’s Party Attacks Brazil’s Voting Systems
item.description: Four days before Brazilians vote, President Jair Bolsonaro’s political party formally claimed, without evidence, that government employees could alter ballots.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil at a rally on Saturday.

item.title: The Last Days of an Outback Town Where Every Breath Can Be Toxic
item.description: The town of Wittenoom, ruined by asbestos mining, will be wiped off the face of the earth. But first the government had to remove those who wanted to stay.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Matthew Abbott
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Once a symbol of economic prosperity, Wittenoom, Australia, is now a ghost town, polluted by decades of asbestos mining.

item.title: Brazil’s Lula Is Out of Prison and Trying to Defeat Bolsonaro
item.description: Former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva is trying to cap a stunning political comeback by defeating the incumbent Jair Bolsonaro in Brazil’s elections on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Flávia Milhorance
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. da Silva has taken to comparing himself to Nelson Mandela, Mahatma Gandhi and Martin Luther King Jr., political prisoners who expanded their movements after they were freed.

item.title: Mexico Named Deadliest Country for Environmental Activists
item.description: A new report from the watchdog group Global Witness found that 54 land rights activists were killed in Mexico last year, the most of any country.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: Mourners attending the burial service for the Indigenous rights leader Tomas Rojo in the Yaqui Indigenous community Vicam, in the Mexican state of Sonora, in July 2021.

item.title: Felicien Kabuga, Rwanda Genocide Tribunal’s Most Wanted, Is on Trial
item.description: Félicien Kabuga lived on the run for 23 years before his arrest in France in 2020. He is accused of backing the groups that oversaw the killing of hundreds of thousands of people in 1994.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Individuals killed during the 1994 Rwandan genocide, from a display at the Kigali Genocide Memorial. At least 800,000 died.

item.title: Myanmar Sentences Australian Economic Adviser to Three Years
item.description: Sean Turnell, arrested five days after the military seized power in a coup, has been convicted by the junta of violating the country’s official secrets act.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Sean Turnell at the Milken Institute 2017 Asia Summit, in Singapore. He was an economic adviser to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi before the coup in 2021, and has been imprisoned since then.

item.title: Sabotaged Pipelines and a Mystery: Who Did It?
item.description: An attack on gas lines under the Baltic Sea exposes the vulnerability of an already jittery Europe. Some officials suggested Moscow was to blame, but with little evidence, others urge caution.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Armed Forces of Denmark, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo from the Danish military showing gas welling up off the coast of Bornholm island on Tuesday.

item.title: Protests in Prague Signal a Troubled Winter Ahead in Europe
item.description: Tens of thousands gathered in the Czech capital for the second such protest in a month, spurred by an energy crisis and rising prices that are affecting countries across Europe.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Protesters demanding the resignation of the Czech government and early parliamentary elections in Wenceslas Square in Prague on Wednesday.

item.title: Chinese Billionaire Richard Liu Faces Sexual Assault Trial in the US
item.description: Richard Liu, also known as Liu Qiangdong, will be one of the few high-profile Chinese figures to face a courtroom jury over sexual assault allegations.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Caroline Yang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liu Jingyao filed a civil suit accusing the Chinese tech billionaire Richard Liu of raping her in Minneapolis in 2018.

item.title: Body of U.S. Mountaineer, Hilaree Nelson, Found After Avalanche in Nepal
item.description: Hilaree Nelson was apparently blown off a cliff while she was skiing down Manaslu, the world’s eighth-highest peak.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Emily Schmall
item.media:description: Hilaree Nelson with her partner, James Morrison, in 2018. The two ascended Manaslu, in Nepal, and were skiing down when she died this week.

item.title: Few South Koreans Are Having Babies. A Mayor’s Answer? More Nannies.
item.description: The mayor of Seoul wants to ease the high cost and low supply of babysitters in the country to encourage more couples to have children.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: The mayor of Seoul, Oh Se-hoon, center, said versions of his proposal implemented in other countries had prompted a rise in the share of women in the labor force.

item.title: Britain’s Gamble on Tax Cuts has Economists Warning of Past Mistakes
item.description: The International Monetary Fund is just one of the many voices that have criticized a plan to cut rates for high earners.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: Liz Truss, Britain’s new prime minister, has staked her fledgling government on a once-in-a-generation package of tax cuts and deregulation meant to energize the economy.

item.title: Vatican Disciplined Nobel Laureate Bishop Over Child Abuse Claims
item.description: After accusations against him became public, the Vatican said that in 2020 it had punished Bishop Carlos Ximenes Belo, a hero of the independence movement in his native East Timor.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Glenn Campbell/The Sydney Morning Herald/Fairfax Media, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Bishop Carlos Ximenes Belo in Dili, East Timor, in 2006.

item.title: Gas Flares Might Release More Methane Than Thought, Study Finds
item.description: Flaring, meant to burn off the planet-warming gas at industrial sites, doesn’t always work as intended, according to researchers.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: A flare in the Permian Basin in Midland, Texas. Methane is a stronger, though shorter-lived, greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide.

item.title: Pentagon Plans to Set Up a New Command to Arm Ukraine, Officials Say
item.description: The mission in Germany would streamline a training and assistance system that the United States and its allies created on the fly after Russia’s invasion, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers heading toward the front line near Kramatorsk, in the country’s east, in May. The Pentagon’s proposal for a new command signals that the United States expects the threat from Russia to persist for many years, current and former senior U.S. officials said.

item.title: Russia Beat and Denied Food to Prisoners of War, Ukraine Says
item.description: Evidence of Russian abuses of captives has fueled outrage and added to a litany of reports of Russian war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Security Service Of Ukraine, via Getty Images
item.media:description: This handout released by Security Service of Ukraine last week shows medical personnel assisting a Ukrainian prisoner of war after a mass prisoner exchange in Chernigiv region, Ukraine.

item.title: Zelensky’s Answer to Escalating Russian Threats: Defiance
item.description: In a nightly address, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine told Russian soldiers: “If you want to live, run.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Russian men who have been drafted saying goodbye to relatives at a recruiting office in Moscow on Tuesday.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth’s Death Certificate Reveals Cause and Time of Death
item.description: Queen Elizabeth died of “old age” at 3:10 p.m. on Sept. 8, the paperwork shows.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II, photographed before receiving Liz Truss for an audience at Balmoral on Sept. 6, two days before she died.

item.title: China’s ‘Absurd’ Covid Propaganda Stirs Rebellion
item.description: The use of propaganda in the country has been on overdrive in the pandemic, with some Chinese citizens arguing the language has bordered on “nonsense.”
item.dc:creator: Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Covid testing booth in Beijing last week. In some cases, Chinese citizens are required to get a coronavirus test three times a week.

item.title: North Korea Fires Two Missiles, Third Test in a Week
item.description: The test took place hours after Vice President Kamala Harris met with South Korea’s president to discuss their nations’ alliance.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: In a Seoul railroad station on Thursday, file footage of earlier North Korean military activity illustrated a news report about its most recent missile launch.

item.title: Hospitals in Coastal Cities Risk Flooding Even in ‘Weak’ Hurricanes, Study Finds
item.description: In a third of the 78 cities examined on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts, half or more of hospitals were at risk from a Category 2 storm, the researchers said.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flood barriers were erected in front of Tampa General Hospital in preparation for Hurricane Ian.

item.title: Finland Closes Border to Russian Tourists
item.description: The long-planned move closes off the last land route into the European Union for people fleeing Russia’s military mobilization effort.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola
item.media:description: Vehicles coming from Russia in line at Finland’s Vaalimaa checkpoint on Wednesday.

item.title: The Kashmiri Chef Foraging on Precarious Soil
item.description: For Prateek Sadhu, gathering native ingredients in the conflict zone where he grew up is the only way of asserting Kashmir’s tenuous place in the world.
item.dc:creator: Ligaya Mishan and Anu Kumar

item.title: What to Know About Ian and Climate Change
item.description: We have the latest on Hurricane Ian, another storm to gather strength with frightening speed.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt, Claire Moses and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tampa, Fla., as Hurricane Ian hit.

item.title: New Infectious Threats Are Coming. The US Probably Won’t Contain Them.
item.description: The coronavirus revealed flaws in the nation’s pandemic plans. The spread of monkeypox shows that the problems remain deeply entrenched.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Flags representing Americans who died of Covid-19, a work by artist Suzanne Brennan Firstenberg, on the National Mall last year.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: A veneer of respectability over Moscow’s land grab.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Russian Proxies in Ukraine Push Moscow to Annex Occupied Regions
item.description: The requests lent an air of formality to a process condemned by the West. They followed sham referendums in four regions in Ukraine that purported to put voters’ stamp of approval on joining Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora and Eric Nagourney
item.media:description: A giant poster in Luhansk, Ukraine, on Wednesday declared, “With Russia forever!” as Russia appeared poised to try to annex the region.

item.title: The Pentagon announces an additional $1.1 billion in long-term aid for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Tony Overman/The Olympian, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A High Mobility Artillery Rocket System (HIMARS) produced by Lockheed Martin during combat training at the Yakima Training Center, Wash.

item.title: What We Know About the Mysterious Nord Stream Pipeline Leaks
item.description: The leaks, which may amount to as much as a third of Denmark’s annual carbon emissions, expose the vulnerability of critical infrastructure as the war in Ukraine continues.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Bernd Wüstneck/picture alliance via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline being laid in the Baltic Sea in 2018.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Iran Strikes Kurds in Iraq
item.description: Plus Australia moves to fight corruption and a Chinese businessman faces assault allegations in a U.S. court.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Smoke rose from the Iraqi Kurdistan headquarters of the Kurdish Democratic Party of Iran on the outskirts of Kirkuk, Iraq, on Wednesday.

item.title: Moscow Releases Final Results of Discredited Ukraine Referendums
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Women hang a Russian flag at their shop in Luhansk, in eastern Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Meeting in Brussels Signifies a Turning Point for Allies Arming Ukraine
item.description: Defense officials responsible for purchasing weapons for more than 40 nations discussed how to ramp up production for a potentially yearslong war.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay and Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Ukrainian forces preparing to fire an American-supplied howitzer in the Kharkiv region in July. More than 40 nations have collaborated to arm Ukraine.

item.title: U.S. and Russia Duel Over Leadership of U.N. Tech Group
item.description: Member countries vote on Thursday for an American or a Russian to lead the International Telecommunication Union, which sets standards for new technologies.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.media:description: Rashid Ismailov of the Russian Federation is standing for election to lead the International Telecommunication Union.

item.title: The E.U. proposes a fresh round of sanctions against the Kremlin over ‘sham’ referendums.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: “Last week, Russia escalated the invasion of Ukraine to a whole new level,” Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission’s president, said Wednesday in in Brussels.

item.title: 4 Palestinians Killed in West Bank During Israeli Raid
item.description: The militants were among more than 90 Palestinians and two Israeli security officials killed in the territory in 2022, as violence continues to surge.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Palestinians attending the funeral of the militants killed during an Israeli Army raid in the West Bank city of Jenin on Wednesday.

item.title: Guinea 2009 Massacre Trial Begins
item.description: In addition to those killed, dozens of women were raped when security forces stormed a pro-democracy rally in 2009, a U.N. investigation found. Eleven men, including the country’s former president, are on trial.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Guinean police arrested a protester on Sept. 28, 2009. Guineans have been waiting for the trial of the former leader Moussa Dadis Camara and those accused of committing a massacre that day.

item.title: At Least 9 Killed as Tensions in Iran Cross the Border Into Iraq
item.description: The Revolutionary Guards Corps has been attacking Kurdish opposition groups in northern Iraq, blaming them for fomenting the unrest in Iran that was set off by the death of Mahsa Amini.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Smoke rose from the Iraqi Kurdistan headquarters of the Kurdish Democratic Party of Iran on the outskirts of Kirkuk, Iraq, on Wednesday.

item.title: At least 150,000 Leave Russia After Putin Announced Partial Military Mobilization
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Georgian police officers blocked opposition activists who were holding a rally near the Russian border on Wednesday to support Ukrainians and protest against the arrival of Russian citizens.

item.title: If Brazil’s President Attempts a Coup, What Will the Police Do?
item.description: If Brazil’s election sparks mass unrest, the country’s so-called military police force would be called upon to restore order, giving them tremendous power to affect outcomes.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil at campaign rally last week.

item.title: Russian-Backed Officials Ask Putin to Annex Ukrainian Regions
item.description: The appeals from Moscow-backed leaders set in motion formalities intended to give Russia’s plans a sheen of legitimacy.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A billboard with a Russian flag reading ‘We believe in our army and our victory’ in Luhansk, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Why Experts and Officials Say Nord Stream Pipleline Leaks Were No Accident
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:description: Facilities of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline in Lubmin, Germany.

item.title: Covid Boosters
item.description: Who should get a Covid booster, and when? We answer the big questions.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Administering Covid boosters in Salt Lake City this month.

item.title: Australia’s Proposed Integrity Commission Would Work Mostly in Secret
item.description: Fulfilling a campaign promise, the government has a plan for an oversight agency to investigate allegations of corruption. Many welcome the move, but not unreservedly.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Mick Tsikas/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Lawmakers in Australia’s House of Representatives at Parliament House this month.

item.title: Cuba Starts Restoring Power After Hurricane Ian Causes Blackout
item.description: Power began coming back on in the east, but it was not clear how much of the electricity had been restored by Wednesday morning.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez
item.media:description: People playing dominoes by flashlight during a blackout in Havana on Wednesday.

item.title: Our Correspondents on the Biggest Music, Shows and Books in Their Parts of the World
item.description: Our reporters are keeping an eye on and an ear out for the buzz in their parts of the world.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Needelman
item.category: The Sex Lives of African Women: Self-discovery, Freedom, and Healing (Book)
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: The Long Road to Driverless Trucks
item.description: Self-driving eighteen-wheelers are now on highways in states like California and Texas. But there are still human “safety drivers” behind the wheel. What will it take to get them out?
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz

item.title: Read Your Way Through Rome
item.description: Igiaba Scego, an author born in Rome to Somali parents, recommends books that draw readers through the rich layers that make up her hometown.
item.dc:creator: Igiaba Scego

item.title: The top E.U. diplomat says the Nord Stream leaks resulted from ‘a deliberate act.’
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk, Melissa Eddy, Oleg Matsnev and Johanna Lemola
item.media:description: This photo released by the Danish military on Tuesday shows gas bubbles from the Nord Stream 2 leak reaching the surface of the Baltic Sea, near the Danish island of Bornholm.

item.title: Far From Routine, Asia Trip Presents Thorny Tests for Kamala Harris
item.description: A visit for Shinzo Abe’s controversial state funeral also includes outreach to Asian allies over military advances by North Korea and China.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris on the Howard, a U.S. naval destroyer, at the Yokosuka base in Japan on Wednesday.

item.title: On Portugal’s ‘Bitcoin Beach,’ Crypto Optimism Still Reigns
item.description: In crypto havens such as Meia Praia beach, the confidence in digital currencies remains undimmed even after this summer’s crash.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cardoso for The New York Times
item.media:description: An access point to Meia Praia, which has become known to some as Bitcoin Beach. It has become a bubble of optimism about cryptocurrency amid a serious downturn for crypto.

item.title: Zambia and Its New President Are Still on Their Honeymoon
item.description: Hakainde Hichilema is hailed as a miracle worker for turning around the fortunes of the southern African country. But with his opposition neutralized and a corruption drive focused on his predecessors, some are uneasy.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Hakainde Hichilema of Zambia.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Suspicious gas leaks in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Armed Forces of Denmark, via Associated Press

item.title: Pipeline breaks look deliberate, Europeans say, exposing vulnerability in vital energy infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy

item.title: As Russians Flee, Some Find Draft Notices Waiting at the Border
item.description: The Kremlin dispatched federal security forces to frontier border crossings packed with Russian men trying to escape the draft by entering countries like Georgia, Kazakhstan and Mongolia.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Andrew E. Kramer and Eric Nagourney
item.media:description: A Georgia-Russia border checkpoint on Monday. Georgia said it would let people enter on foot, and its interior minister said about 10,000 people were seeking entry into the country each day.

item.title: CIA Warned Europe of Potential Attacks on Nord Stream Pipelines
item.description: The warning was not specific, the officials said, and they declined to say whether Russia was identified as a possible attacker.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Karine Jean-Pierre, the White House press secretary, said the Biden administration would not speculate on the cause of the pipeline damage.

item.title: Nord Stream Pipeline Breaks Look Deliberate, Europeans Say
item.description: The leaks in the Nord Stream under the Baltic Sea heightened fears of shortages because of the clash with Russia, and showed how vital infrastructure could be at risk.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia Suspected of Pipeline Sabotage
item.description: Plus a typhoon heads toward Vietnam and a thwarted Chinese attempt to influence U.S. elections.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Lauren Hard

item.title: At the United Nations, Zelensky rails against Russia for trying to ‘steal’ Ukrainian territory.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine addressing members of the U.N. Security Council by video on Tuesday.

item.title: Truss Takes a Bold Economic Gamble. Will It Sink Her Government?
item.description: Three weeks into her term, Prime Minister Liz Truss’s financial plans have thrown the markets and Britain’s currency into chaos and put her future in peril.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Support for the Conservative Party, led by Prime Minister Liz Truss, has plunged in the polls.

item.title: Prince Mohammed bin Salman Named Saudi Prime Minister
item.description: The crown prince, who has already been the kingdom’s de facto ruler for several years, previously served as deputy prime minister under King Salman, as well as defense minister.
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.category: Khaled bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia, who has been first in line to succeed his father as king since 2017, was named prime minister on Tuesday.
